text: I don't really know. It was really clear in my mind that it was the future and I thought the investors were wrong, frankly. But investors also gave really helpful feedback and feedback often in the form of rejection. So they would say, "Oh, your market's not big enough." And I would say, "It's going to be huge." And I'd add a new page in my pitch deck that said how big the market I believe was.
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny asks Melanie about how it felt to be rejected by over 100 investors early on, especially given that Canva is now a $40+ billion company. Melanie explains that despite the constant rejections, she remained convinced that her vision represented the future of design. She describes how she used investor feedback constructively - when investors said her market wasn't big enough or that she was the same as competitors, she would add new slides to her pitch deck addressing these concerns and demonstrating the market opportunity and competitive differentiation.
vocabulary_highlights: feedback often in the form of rejection
text_ko: 잘 모르겠어요. 제게는 그게 미래라는 게 정말 분명했고, 솔직히 투자자들이 틀렸다고 생각했어요. 하지만 투자자들로부터 정말 도움이 되는 피드백도 많이 받았고, 그 피드백은 종종 거절의 형태로 왔어요. 투자자들은 "아, 시장(market)이 충분히 크지 않아요."라고 했고, 저는 "엄청 커질 거예요."라고 답했어요. 그리고 제가 생각하는 시장 규모를 보여 주는 새 페이지를 피치덱(pitch deck)에 하나 더 넣었어요.
text_zh: 我也说不清楚。反正在我心里特别确定这就是未来的趋势，老实说我觉得那些投资人都看走眼了。不过投资人也给了挺有用的反馈，虽然这些反馈经常是以拒绝的形式出现的。他们会说，"你这个市场不够大。"我就回他们，"这市场会很大的。"然后我就在我的路演(pitch deck)里加一页，专门讲我认为这个市场能有多大。
text_es: No tenía muy claro la verdad. Para mí estaba clarísimo que eso era el futuro y pensaba que los inversionistas estaban equivocados, te digo la verdad. Pero los inversionistas también me dieron retroalimentación súper útil, aunque muchas veces en forma de rechazo. Me decían cosas como "Tu mercado no es lo suficientemente grande" y yo les contestaba "Va a ser enorme." Y entonces agregaba una página nueva a mi presentación explicando qué tan grande creía yo que iba a ser el mercado.

text: So we have this concept of chaos to clarity and every idea starts in the chaos side, and then you have to work all the way to the other side, which is clarity. That very first step at the far end of chaos was quite an embarrassing step actually, because you don't have mastery at that point. You don't have all the answers.
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny asks Melanie about how she operationalizes her Column B thinking approach, specifically mentioning that Canva creates vision decks for every project. Melanie explains Canva's "chaos to clarity" framework - every new idea begins in chaos (just a vague concept in your head) and must progress through incremental steps toward clarity (becoming more concrete and visible to others). She acknowledges that the initial step feels embarrassing because you don't have expertise yet, but emphasizes the importance of taking that first step anyway.
text_ko: 우리는 '혼돈에서 명확성으로(chaos to clarity)'라는 개념이 있어요. 모든 아이디어는 혼돈 쪽에서 시작해서 반대편인 명확성까지 쭉 작업을 해나가야 해요. 혼돈의 가장 끝자락에서 뗀 그 첫걸음은 사실 꽤 민망해요. 그때는 마스터리(mastery)가 없고, 모든 답을 가지고 있지 않거든요.
text_zh: 我们有个"从混乱到清晰"的概念，每个想法一开始都是混乱的，然后你得一路摸索到另一头，也就是清晰的状态。其实在混乱那端迈出第一步是很尴尬的，因为那时候你还没掌握要领，也没有现成的答案。
text_es: Entonces tenemos este concepto de caos a claridad, y cada idea empieza del lado del caos, y después tienes que trabajar hasta llegar al otro extremo, que es la claridad. Ese primer paso allá en el extremo del caos fue bastante incómodo la verdad, porque en ese momento no dominas el tema. No tienes todas las respuestas.

text: The thing that I love about a crazy big goal is that you feel completely inadequate before it. You want to work really hard to will it into existence. I really like to start by just imagining what is the future that you actually want Right now? I have a wall in my house in my office, which is my vision for what I'd like the world to look like in 2050.
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny asks about Canva's value of "Crazy Big Goals" and why having such ambitious goals is so important. Melanie explains that crazy big goals are powerful because they make you feel inadequate, which motivates you to work extremely hard to achieve them. She emphasizes starting by imagining the ideal future you want to create, and mentions that she has a physical vision wall in her office showing what she wants the world to look like by 2050.
text_ko: 엄청 크게 잡은 목표의 좋은 점은 그 목표 앞에서는 스스로가 완전히 부족하다고 느낀다는 거예요. 그래서 그걸 현실로 만들기 위해 정말 열심히 일하게 돼요. 저는 보통 지금 당장 내가 진짜로 원하는 미래가 어떤 건지 상상하는 것부터 시작하는 걸 정말 좋아해요. 집에 있는 제 작업실 벽 한쪽에는 2050년쯤 세상이 어떤 모습이길 바라는지에 대한 제 비전(vision)을 붙여놨어요.
text_zh: 我特别喜欢那种疯狂大目标的地方就是，面对它你会觉得自己完全不够格。这会让你特别想拼命去把它变成现实。我很喜欢从想象开始——你到底想要什么样的未来？现在我家办公室的墙上贴着我对2050年世界的愿景图。
text_es: Lo que me encanta de una meta súper ambiciosa es que te sientes completamente incapaz frente a ella. Te dan ganas de trabajar durísimo para hacerla realidad. Me gusta mucho empezar simplemente imaginando cuál es el futuro que realmente quieres. Ahora mismo tengo una pared en mi oficina en casa que es mi visión de cómo me gustaría que se viera el mundo en 2050.

text: I think it's sort of the dark tunnel analogy. Or chaos to clarity, let's go with that one. It's a slightly friendlier analogy and I think just taking the rejection and turning into things that you can control. So I can control my pitch deck, I can control the number of people I'm speaking to and I just spoke to literally everyone.
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny asks Melanie for advice for founders who are struggling with fundraising, given her experience of being rejected by over 100 investors. Melanie suggests using her "chaos to clarity" framework and focusing on what you can control when facing rejection. Rather than taking rejections personally, she recommends channeling that feedback into improving controllable elements like your pitch deck and expanding the number of investors you talk to.
vocabulary_highlights: turning into things that you can control
text_ko: 저는 이걸 일종의 '어두운 터널' 비유(dark tunnel analogy) 같다고 생각해요. 아니면 '혼돈에서 명료함으로(chaos to clarity)'—그걸로 할게요. 그게 좀 더 친근한 비유고, 거절을 받아들이고 그걸 내가 통제할 수 있는 것들로 바꾸는 거예요. 예를 들어 피치덱(pitch deck)은 제가 관리할 수 있고, 제가 만나는 사람 수도 제가 조절할 수 있어요. 그래서 저는 말 그대로 모든 사람에게 다 이야기했어요.
text_zh: 我觉得这就像是从混乱到清晰的过程，用这个比喻更友好一些。关键是要把被拒绝这件事转化成你能掌控的东西。比如说，我可以控制我的路演材料(pitch deck)，我可以控制接触多少人，所以我就是见人就聊，逢人就讲。
text_es: Creo que es como la analogía del túnel oscuro. O mejor dicho, del caos a la claridad, vamos con esa que suena más amigable. Se trata de tomar el rechazo y convertirlo en cosas que sí puedes controlar. O sea, yo puedo controlar mi pitch deck, puedo controlar con cuántas personas hablo, y literalmente hablé con todo el mundo.

text: I think it was kind of everything internally. We made it into a bit of a game. We had this game board and I bought these little rubber ducky sort of bath toys and we had, so we all the little components represented as a bath toy on this board and there was all these stages of went launched in product. There was an emergency lane at the end of it was home and hosed.
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny asks about the internal mood during Canva's two-year period when they had to rewrite their entire codebase and couldn't ship any new product features. Melanie describes how the team dealt with this challenging time by gamifying the process. They created a board game with rubber duck toys representing different components, with various stages leading to product launch, including an "emergency lane" that ended at "home and hosed" (Australian slang meaning safe or completed).
vocabulary_highlights: made it into a bit of a game
rubber ducky sort of bath toys
text_ko: 사실 내부적으로는 전부 다 그런 식이었던 것 같아요. 우리는 이걸 약간 게임처럼 만들었어요. 게임판(game board)을 하나 만들어서 제가 작은 고무오리(rubber ducky) 같은 목욕 장난감들을 몇 개 샀고, 제품의 작은 구성 요소들을 그 장난감으로 게임판 위에 표시해 놨죠. 제품 출시(product launch)의 여러 단계가 다 보이게 해두고, 마지막에는 비상 레인(emergency lane)이 있어서 거기까지 가면 '끝났다, 해결됐다' 같은 상태가 되는 식이었어요.
text_zh: 我觉得内部什么招都用上了。我们把它搞成了一个小游戏的形式。我们做了个游戏板，我还买了那种小橡皮鸭子洗澡玩具，然后把所有的小模块都用这些小鸭子在板子上代表，产品发布有好多个阶段。最后还设了个紧急通道，走到头就算大功告成了。
text_es: Creo que fue un poco de todo internamente. Lo convertimos en una especie de juego. Teníamos este tablero de juego y compré estos patitos de goma, como juguetes de baño, y teníamos todos los componentes representados como juguetes de baño en este tablero. Había todas estas etapas por las que pasaba el producto cuando se lanzaba. Había un carril de emergencia y al final estaba la meta donde ya teníamos todo listo y controlado.

text: We are giving away 1.5 billion of product a year now. And so the impact that that can have and the ripple effect of that I think is pretty great. And I think for all of us, it gives a lot more meaning to our work than, "Get Rich."
speaker: Melanie Perkins
context: Lenny notes that many companies have philanthropic initiatives that aren't central to their operations, but observes that Canva's two-step plan (build a valuable company, then do good) seems core to how the company operates. Melanie explains the scope of Canva's giving, including their education product used by 100 million people monthly and their nonprofit program. She emphasizes that giving away $1.5 billion worth of product annually creates meaningful ripple effects and provides the team with deeper purpose beyond just financial success.
vocabulary_highlights: lot more meaning to our work
text_ko: 지금은 연간 15억 규모의 제품을 무료로 나눠주고 있어요. 그래서 그로 인한 영향과 파급 효과(ripple effect)가 꽤 크다고 생각해요. 그리고 우리 모두에게 그건 단순히 '부자 되기'(Get Rich)보다 훨씬 더 큰 의미를 줘요.
text_zh: 我们现在每年免费提供15亿美元的产品。这个影响力和连锁反应我觉得挺厉害的。对我们所有人来说，这比单纯"发财致富"给工作带来了更多意义。
text_es: Ahora estamos regalando productos por valor de 1.5 mil millones al año. Y el impacto que eso puede tener, con todo el efecto dominó que genera, me parece increíble. Y creo que para todos nosotros, eso le da mucho más sentido a nuestro trabajo que simplemente "hacerse rico."
